person:biography.personal-details:content: Amy Buck earned her PhD in Biochemistry at the University of Colorado, Boulder, where she studied RNA-protein dynamics in the RNase P ribozyme in the lab of Prof. Norman Pace. She moved to the University of Edinburgh in 2005 and was awarded a Marie Curie Incoming International Fellowship to study the functions of microRNAs in viral infection at the Division of Pathway Medicine. In 2009, she was awarded a BBSRC New Investigator award and an Advanced Fellowship at the University of Edinburgh to build her research group on microRNA function and regulation in viral infection. In 2012 she was awarded a Wellcome Trust Research Career Development Fellowship to study microRNA-virus interactions and to develop a new line of research in RNA secretion by nematode parasites. Her lab studies trans-genome RNA-RNA interactions, both in the context of viral-host interactions and in parasite-host interactions in the gut.
